Article: SAN JOSE, Calif. â 5G cellular is a technology with many faces poised for a phased roll starting late this year. An AT&T lab manager in Austin sketched out the challenges making it happen. AT&T announced plans to make the 3GPP Release 15 version of 5G available in 12 markets before the end of the year. It will initially use a so-called hockey puck that supports high-speed Wi-Fi for consumer and business devices and links to the cellular net over 5G using the 28-GHz band. âDepending on the vendor, [the pucks use] 400- or 800-MHz channels, and in all cases, we see gigabit-type data rates that are pretty reliable,â said Dave Wolter, an assistant vice president for radio technology at AT&T who runs the lab. So far, âwe see some rain fade, but weather has not been as big a factor as some thought because the links are short â about 100 to 300 meters â and even the farthest links still get a Gbit/second, with probably more possible when you have line of sight.â Currently the lab does not have equipment hardened for outdoor use. Thus, signals have some attenuation passing through windows. The next big leap, expected in 2019, is supporting mobile broadband on handsets and other devices. To get ready, the lab is conducting tests from a van in an area of Austin where it has set up four antennas. Itâs still early days in a limited test area for beamforming. So far, the system handles 28-GHz handoffs between base stations with line of sight while the van moves at 25 mph. Using client antennas that are better than what actual handsets are expected to employ, devices have not dropped links and have hit data rates above 1.5 Gbits/s.
